column1: Mexican rebel Pancho Villa lead a revolution helped by an American aviator imprisonned in Mexico.::Jo Blo

Pulled into the Mexican Revolution by his own greed Texas gunrunner & pilot Lee Arnold joins bandit-turned-patriot Pancho Villa & his band of dedicated men in a march across Mexico battling the Colorados & stealing women's hearts as they go. But each has a nemesis among his friends: Arnold is tormented by Fierro Villa's right-hand-man
column2: and Villa must face possible betrayal by his own president's naiveté.::Steve83

column1: Amidst turbulence and turmoil in early-20th century Mexico the popular outlaw leader and a true hero of the Mexican revolution Pancho Villa captures the American gun-running pilot Lee Arnold who smuggles arms for the enemy in his small biplane. To save himself Lee strikes a deal with Villa and his tough lieutenant Fierro to aid their cause by using his remarkable set of skills
column2: however their victories will soon get in the eye of the imperious General Huerta Villa's superior. The trap to get Pancho out of the way is already set. Can the gringo and his small aeroplane save the Mexican leader?::Nick Riganas

column1: The true story of a daring raid on Japanese-occupied Singapore Harbour by Australian and British troops during WWII.::Alexander Lum

On 11 September 1944 a squad of 23 Australian and British soldiers lead by Lieutanant-Colonel Ivan Lyon leave Fremantle bound for Indonesia as part of Operation Rimau an attempted repeat of the highly-successful Operation Jaywick the previous year in which nearly sixty ships in Japanese-occupied Singapore Harbour were destroyed.::Alexander Lum
